author: Graeme Whitfield
title: Newcastle technology giant Sage will stay in city whatever happens in EU referendum
text:
Newcastle technology giant Sage will stay in city whatever happens in EU referendum 18:01, 13 Jun 2016 18:02, 13 Jun 2016 By Graeme Whitfield Sage is maintaining a neutral stance on the June 23 vote, saying people do not need to be swayed by big business Shares Get business news by email Stephen Kelly 
The head of one of the North East’s largest employers has said his company’s presence in the region will not be affected by the EU referendum - and insisted that it will stay neutral on the issue. 
Technology giant Sage today held an EU debate to which it invited around 100 North East companies, with the event also being live streamed to many more of the firm’s customers around the country. 
Other business leaders in the North East - including the heads of companies like Nissan, Hitachi and Virgin Money - have spoken out in favour of the UK remaining in the EU, saying Brexit would be damaging to their companies and to jobs in the North East. 
But Sage CEO Stephen Kelly insisted that Sage would be “passionately and positively neutral” in the debate because it did not believe that voters were listening to the voices of big business. 
Instead the firm saw its role as helping to provide information to its customers - mainly small and medium-sized business owners - to help them make an informed decision in the June 23 referendum. 
Mr Kelly was speaking after an event his company had staged an event at the Sage Gateshead which saw Alchemists’ chief executive Lucy Armstrong and Herb Kim from Thinking Digital debating against author and columnist Matt Ridley and Andy Saunders, chairman of Business for Britain North East. 
Mr Kelly said: “The company’s responsibility is to shine a spotlight on the issues, the facts and the data. It’s for the voters of this country to make their informed decision. 
“One of the things we’ve done is survey all our customers and less than 1% said they were going to be influenced by the celebrities, the big personalities, politicians or big businesses coming out one way or the other.” 
Mr Kelly said much of the EU debate so far had been “myopic and quite hysterical”, though he felt there had been some improvements in recent days. 
Asked whether Sage would remain based in Newcastle if the country votes for Brexit, Mr Kelly said: “Absolutely. This is our spiritual home, the North East is important to us and we’re the largest private sector employer in Newcastle. 
“Furthermore, we’ve done the analysis internally and we anticipate, unless something cataclysmic happens - which we don’t anticipate - the business would carry on and the impact would be immaterial.” 
In yesterday’s debate, Lucy Armstrong and Herb Kim made the case for remaining in the EU, with Ms Armstrong saying that the the country was better off remaining part of the organisation so that it could influence its rules. 
Pro-Brexit campaign Matt Ridley said the EU “encourages antagonism to innovation” and argued that the UK would be better off outside of the organisation.
